description: From Middle English rose, roose, from Old English rōse, from Latin rosa, of uncertain origin but possibly via Oscan from Ancient Greek ῥόδον (rhódon, “rose”) (Aeolic ϝρόδον (wródon)), from Old Persian *wṛda- (“flower”) (compare Avestan 𐬬𐬀𐬭𐬆𐬜𐬀-‎ (varəδa-), Sogdian ward, Parthian wâr, late Middle Persian [Term?] (gwl /gul/), Persian گل‎ (gol, “rose, flower”), and Middle Iranian borrowings including Old Armenian վարդ (vard, “rose”), Aramaic וַרְדָּא‎ (wardā) / ܘܪܕܐ‎ (wardā), Arabic وَرْدَة‎ (warda), Hebrew וֶרֶד‎ (wéreḏ)), from Proto-Indo-European *wr̥dʰos (“sweetbriar”) (compare Old English word (“thornbush”), Latin rubus (“bramble”), Albanian hurdhe (“ivy”)). Possibly ultimately a derivation from a verb for "to grow" only attested in Indo-Iranian (*Hwardʰ-, compare Sanskrit वर्धति (vardhati), with relatives in Avestan).

entries.meaning: Having a purplish-red or pink colour. See rosy.
A shrub of the genus Rosa, with red, pink, white or yellow flowers.
A flower of the rose plant.
examples: O my Luve's like a red, red roseThat's newly sprung in june...

entries.meaning: A plant or species in the rose family. (Rosaceae)
(heraldry) The rose flower, usually depicted with five petals, five barbs, and a circular seed.
(countable, uncountable) A purplish-red or pink colour, the colour of some rose flowers.
A round nozzle for a sprinkling can or hose.
The usually circular base of a light socket in the ceiling, from which the fitting or chandelier is suspended.
Any of various large, red-bodied, papilionid butterflies of the genus Pachliopta.
(mathematics) Any of various flower-like polar graphs of sinusoids or their squares.
(mathematics, graph theory) A graph with only one vertex.

verbs.description: rose (third-person singular simple present roses, present participle rosing, simple past and past participle rosed)

entries.meaning: (poetic, transitive) To make rose-coloured; to redden or flush.
(poetic, transitive) To perfume, as with roses.

description: See the etymology of the corresponding lemma form.

entries.meaning: (now colloquial and nonstandard) past participle of rise
